_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Portable hand held meters and Sprinkler system activates fire alarm
_prev_prog_3.Description: Administrave Controls - Starts with a paper trail.  A certificate of Analysis and the Bill of Lading arrive with the material.  The reciever checks the paper work for accuracy then forwards this to their supervisor for a double check from management then signed and dated. The truck is then backed up into an intrinsically safe unloading area with numerous safeguards to prevent release of pentane.  These safeguards include the HMI that will not allow material to be pumped if its max volume is reached, the scully system to ensure the process if thouroughly grounded before allowing the material to be pumped.  There are also both stationary and portable LEL detectors being used to ensure the atmospheric conditions do not reach an explosive level.  Only qualified operators shall perform these tasks and their competency in these tasks are evaluated by their supervisor or a member of management knowledgeable in these tasks.  There is no smoking permitted on this property except in designated smoking areas that have been determine to be safe from the process.  The mixing room that has a 2 hour fire rating is where the Pentane is added into the process. This room is monitored with stationary LEL detectors and has an exhaust fan to evacuate an accumulation of vapors.  The mixture is then pumped into a batch system and from there is pumped to the pour table that is also monitored by staionary LEL detectors.  There is an exhaust fan that will evacuate the volitile material should the concentration reach its control limits.  There are alarm levels built into the system.  With any mechanical deivation an alarm will sound requiring the operator to correct the situation.  At a 15% concentration of pentane an alarm along with a white strobe light will flash and shut the system down and activate the exhaust fan.  At a 40% concentration of Pentane the emergency alarm will sound requiring all employees to evacuate the building and call for the Jacksonville Fire and Rescue department to assit.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility:

  Risk Management and Safety have been important concerns at Johns Manville.  The Risk Management program and Process Safety Program formalizes and documents these activities.  Johns Manville is committed to conducting its operation in a safe, responsible manner and to reducing risks to health and the environment.



A description of your facility and the regulated substance handled:

  This facility manufacturers Polyisocyanurate insulation panels for the construction industry.  A flammable mixture containing two related substances, n-Pentane and Isopentane is used in the manufacturing process.



The worst case and alternative release scenarios:

  The hypothetical worst case scenario is a failure of the 30,000 gallon storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (90%) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  According to hazard modeling software, using the worst case assumptions, impacts from this explosion could cause injuries and damage property located in an area between the storage tank and the hazard endpoint.  The hazard endpoint in this case corresponds to an overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi) and is estimated to extend .4 miles from the storage tank.

  The alternative release scenario involves a hose rupture caused by a truck that pulls away while the hose is still connected to the Pentane tank.  This would result in a spill of approximately 7 gallons (this amount is the maximum quantity of pentane that could be in the hose.)  If a spark were to ignite the spilled liquid and vapors, of the resulting explosion could impact persons or property located within 150 feet of the unloading area.



The general accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps:

  A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of a Pentane release in accordance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Managem

ent (PSM) standard and the EPA Risk Management Program.  This prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents.  Some of the specific activities in the prevention program are described below.

  An in-depth Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the system was conducted prior to start up and numerous risk reduction measures have been implemented.  Qualified personnel will revalidate the PHA every five years.

  The Pentane system was designed in accordance with all applicable codes and standards (NFPA, ANSI, ASME, ect.)  A Pre start up safety review confirmed that the construction and equipment comply with design specifications.

  Written operating procedures are used for training and directing the work of operators, who will receive refresher training at least every three years.

  Critical equipment is maintained, tested and inspected on a planned periodic basis to ensure proper operating conditions.



Five year accident history:

  An employee report that he collected approximately 2 gallons pentane in a catch bucket that came from the Nitrogen line, when he was disconnecting the lines immediately after an unload.  During the investigation we verified that all operating procedures were followed.  We were not able to identify what the root cause was, this was the first and only time an event like this has taken place.  This event took place on January 6, 2009.



The emergency response program:

  A written emergency response plan is maintained at the facility, and our personnel are trained in proper notification and evacuation procedures.  In the event of an emergency, this facility would request immediate assistance from the Jacksonville Fire and Rescue Department.



Planned changes to improve safety:

 Safety has been a part of the working culture at Johns Manville.  The Pentane process is current state of the art and is designed to be as safe as feasibly possible.  At this time, no further improvements are planned.
